description: From Middle English whele (“boil”), from Old English *hwele (“boil”); related to Old English hwelian (“to fester, ulcerate”). Compare also Old English hwelca, hwylca (“an inflamed swelling, pustule”).

entries.meaning: A small raised swelling on the skin, often itchy, caused by a blow from a whip or an insect bite etc.

verbs.description: wheal (third-person singular simple present wheals, present participle whealing, simple past and past participle whealed)

examples: The four last-mentioned mines, Wheal Crowndale, Wheal Crebor, East Liscombe, and Wheal Tamar, are on the same lode, which ranges as usual from east to west, and are included in a space of about four miles in length.
